questions.text: A 24-year-old patient has been given an intradermal injection of 0.1ml PPD (5 tuberculin units) over the forearm.   After 72 hrs, the site is examined as shown in the image below. What is the interpretation of the result obtained?

choices.text: Tuberculin test negative, suggesting immunity from TB
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting an active infection
Tuberculin test negative, suggesting a recent or past infection
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting a recent or past infection

questions.solution:
The above image shows an induration of >10 mm after 72 hrs of intradermal PPD injection suggesting a positive tuberculin test(TST), indicating recent or past infection. 

In TST, 0.1 ml of PPD (purified protein derivative) containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally and induration is read after 48-72 hours. An induration of 10 mm or more is considered positive in patients from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Surrounding erythema is not considered. 

A positive tuberculin test indicates hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein, denoting either latent infection with tubercle bacilli, or BCG immunization, or recent or past infection with or without clinical disease. 

False positives may be seen in infections with related mycobacteria and false negatives in miliary tuberculosis, severely immunosuppressed states, etc. 

Related Pearl: Tuberculin reaction size & candidates for treatment of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection

Risk Group Positive Tuberculin Reaction Size
HIV infected persons ≥5 mm
Recent contacts of a patient with TB ≥5 mm
Organ transplant recipients ≥5 mm
Persons with fibrotic lesions consistent with old TB on chest radiography ≥5 mm
Immunosuppressed persons ≥5 mm
Persons with high risk medical conditions (silicosis & end stage renal disease) ≥5 mm
Injection drug users ≥10 mm
Mycobacteriology lab personnel ≥10 mm
Children <5 years of age ≥10 mm
Recent immigrants from high prevalence countries

≥10 mm
Low-risk persons

           ≥15 mm

 

Tuberculin reactions are read at 48-72 hr as the transverse diameter of the induration, and the diameter of the erythema is NOT considered.

questions.text: The image below shows the model of a skeletal muscle fiber. Which of the following structures is affected in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the image represents dystrophin protein (a sarcolemmal protein), which is absent in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) due to a mutation in the dystrophin gene.

This gene is located on the short arm of chromosome X near the p21 locus (Xp21). Lack of dystrophin leads to cellular instability, which leads to progressive leakage of intracellular components.

ETEPLIRSEN is the first drug approved by FDA to treat patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). It is specifically indicated for patients who have a confirmed mutation of the dystrophin gene amenable to exon 51 skipping, which affects approximately 13-14% of the patients with DMD.

Note- The FDA has approved Vamorolone, a novel corticosteroid for the treatment of DMD. The drug offers enhanced anti-inflammatory properties and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonism as well. It is potentially a safer and more effective alternative to glucocorticoids.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient is given below. It is characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above peripheral smear shows basophilic stippling. It is characteristic of 5' nucleotidase deficiency.

Pyrimidine 5'-nucleotidase (P5'N-1) deficiency is the third most common enzyme abnormality causing hereditary hemolytic anemia. It is an autosomal recessive trait.  

The hallmark of this enzyme deficiency is the presence of pronounced basophilic stippling and accumulation of pyrimidine nucleotides (RNA remnants) within erythrocytes. 

Cabot rings may also be seen. They are thin, threadlike, red to violet rings or figure-of-8 shaped inclusions in red blood cells. They are remnants of the mitotic spindle and are seen in conditions causing dyserythropoiesis.

Basophilic stippling is also seen in the following conditions:

  • Lead toxicity
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Severe thalassemia
  • Conditions with impaired cell division

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows "string-of-beads" feature seen in fibromuscular dysplasia.

The sign is caused by areas of relative stenoses alternating with small aneurysms.

Fibromuscular dysplasia may affect any medium-sized artery in the body and is commonly multifocal and bilateral (up to 60% when involving the renal arteries).

questions.text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. 

If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability.

Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

DIEP flap, TRAM flap, and LD flap are autogenous tissues used in breast reconstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following condition has the given ECG changes?
questions.solution:
The given ECG clearly depicts the Delta wave at the start of QRS complex. It is characteristic of WPW syndrome.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles.

ECG Feature:

  • P-R interval <120 ms
  • Slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the "Delta wave"
    • WPW pattern "Type A": Positive delta waves in all precordial leads, with small or absent S waves
    • WPW pattern "Type B": A delta wave is negative, with prominent S waves, in right precordial leads
  • The QRS complex as a whole is slightly widened
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the  following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of walls in the day time?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis.

Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:

  • Kala-azar
  • Oriental sore
  • Sandfly fever
  • Oroya fever

Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.

Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly(Simulium) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

questions.text: Identify this congenital anomaly found on the MRI image of a neonate.
questions.solution:
The given axial T1 weighted image demonstrates the typical figure of eight sign consistent in a neonate with lissencephaly. This disorder results from defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th and 14th weeks of gestation, leading to a poor development or absence of gyri and sulci, thickened cortex, and shallow, widened Sylvian fissures, contributing to the above radiographic appearance. Other associated anomalies may include agenesis or hypoplasia of the corpus callosum or septum pellucidum. 

The following image shows the figure of eight sign of lissencephaly:

Other options:

Option A: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and inadequate induction of forebrain structures. The pancake brain sign represents the appearance of the cerebral parenchyma in the case of alobar holoprosencephaly.

Option C: Schizencephaly is the presence of unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres due to an abnormality of morphogenesis. 

Option D: Porencephaly is an extremely rare cephalic disorder involving encephalomalacia. It is a neurological disorder of the central nervous system characterized by cysts or cavities within the cerebral hemisphere.

The above image shows a loss of foveal reflex and central serous retinopathy, therefore showing focal foveal detachment.

There is oedema at the fovea signifying foveal detachment from underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Macular oedema is also present (grey dull retina with a ring reflex around the site of oedema). Thus, the most appropriate choice would be foveal detachment.

Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to increased permeability of choriocapillaris, leading to fluid accumulation in the subretinal space. Therefore, it is now known as central serous choriopathy (CSC).

If there is serous retinal detachment at macula, there is sudden painless loss of vision. Patients also have relative positive scotoma, micropsia and metamorphopsia. On ophthalmoscopy, a circular ring reflex present. The foveal reflex is absent. On fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), an enlarging ink-blot pattern or smoke-stack pattern is seen.

Treatment is generally not required. It is usually self-limiting, but often recurrent. Steroids are contraindicated.

questions.text: The CT abdomen of a patient with Budd-Chiari syndrome shows enlargement of the structure marked X in the image. Identify the structure.
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is the caudate lobe of the liver. Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in Budd-Chiari syndrome.

This segment is unique in that it receives blood supply from both the right and left portal veins and hepatic arteries. It directly drains into the inferior vena cava.

It also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen.

The image given below shows the posterior surface of the liver.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III
